title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 4 march [1873]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 4 March [1873]
text: 1873marchMarch 4 5 oclocko'clockdear waltWalti suppose you have got my letter i wrote last saturdaySaturday as soon as i received yours with the money i thought you would feel rather anxious untilluntil you knew) its being directed to georgeGeorge at the foundry one would suppose it was a business letter it came all safe waltWalt in your letter you wrote sundaySunday you didentdidn't say how you was getting along you must tell me every particular every time you write i doodo want you to get well so bad i dontdon't know what to doodo) the time seems as long to me as it does to you) i feel as if i wanted to doodo something for you walterWalter dear)louLou got a very nice letter yesterday from hatteeHatty poor dear child she talks like a woman and more sensible than many) she said her papa thought he and she and jessieJessie would go to board to mrMr. BuckleysBulkley that they had offered to take them and mrsMrs. bucklyBulkley be a kind of mother to me and little jessieJessie poor hattieHattie it made the tears come in my eyes every time i read it but she said it wasentwasn't like your own relativesbut her papa thought it was the next best thing for them) i was very glad to hear the arrangement i think itsit's much better than keeping house poor little girls i hope their father will be spared to them hattyHatty sent me a rose that was on poor mamasmama's coffin she said) if she could see her dear grandma) every few lines she would say how her dear mama talked so much about grandmai think by what i have heard them speak of mrMr. and mrsMrs. buckleyBuckley they are very good folks) i think jeffyJeffy takes his bereavement very hard)i have got a letter to day from maryMary we wrote to her of mattyMatty death she says if she lives she will come and see me she felt very bad about your ilnessillness but hoped you had got over it she wants you to come to see them i wish dear walt you and i could go down there when it comes hot weather i think it would doodo us both good so we must both get so we can walk without limpinggood bie my dear dear waltWaltmrsMrs.pricePrice was very glad to get your letter write just how you get along it is very cold here to day good beibye Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 4 March [1873]
